etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Orosius' History. Comparative of nigh

definitions: Nearer, closer (in space, time, kinship, etc.). In attributive use. That is the nearer of two things or people; (also, in Old English) †later in time (obsolete). In Old English also as noun In later use: left-hand; chiefly in "nar horse", "nar leg", "nar side".

notes.text: The left hand side of a horse was the one beside which the ploughman walked, hence the closer side.

etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in The Chronicle of Robert of Gloucester. From early Scandinavian. Old Icelandic naer, naerri were used in both comparative and positive sense; in modern Icelandic naer (the reflex of both naer and naerr) is used only in comparative sense (except in compounds), and naerri only in positive sense
